152.text: The power of stories has long been recognised.

154.text: Stretching back into the earliest human records,

161.text: to teach, to galvanise, or simply to entertain.

231.text: Appel and Richter got subjects to read fictional passages

253.text: as well as a higher level of certainty in those beliefs.

482.text: Cooperation is observed throughout the natural world.

485.text: A remarkable example can be seen among hermit crabs,

488.text: who use abandoned shells as a home.

490.text: As they grow, they have to find progressively larger shells to contain them.

495.text: When a large unused shell washes up on a beach,

497.text: hermit crabs of all sizes can be seen to gather round it,

501.text: and sort themselves into a cue of ascending size.

504.text: They’ll each then move into the next larger shell,

509.text: Do they behave this way because they’re aspiring

511.text: to some moral or religious virtue? Of course not.

515.text: They’ve learned to cooperate because it brings mutual benefit.

518.text: Just like we have. Even at the age of twelve,

521.text: I knew full well that the most greedy, self-serving individuals

525.text: would be among the first to feed each other with those long spoons,

529.text: not out of love for their fellow human

532.text: but because they recognised what was good for them.
